snippet: The publication Southern Weekend appeared on newsstands, but the newspaper remains at the forefront of the dispute over government control.
abstract: Protests over censored article in Chinese newspaper Southern Weekend have died down and paper is published more or less on schedule after journalists accept compromise in which propaganda officials promise to loosen some of more intrusive censorship controls; paper, which has been at forefront of changes in news industry, is likely to remain battleground over Communist Party censorship.

byline.original: By EDWARD WONG and CHRIS BUCKLEY
byline.contributor: Edward Wong reported from Guangzhou, and Chris Buckley from Hong Kong. Jonathan Ansfield and Shi Da contributed reporting from Beijing.

lead_paragraph: The publication Southern Weekend appeared on newsstands, but the newspaper remains at the forefront of the dispute over government control.

headline.seo: As Protest Ends, Chinese Censorship Battle Remains
headline.main: Chinese Newspaper Protests End, but Battle Over Censorship Is Unresolved
headline.print_headline: Chinese Newspaper Protests End, but Battle Over Censorship Is Unresolved
